mn106:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.
mn106:3.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
mn106:4.1: “Mendicants, sensual pleasures are impermanent, baseless, false, and deceptive,
mn106:4.2: made by illusion, cooed over by fools.
mn106:4.3: Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:4.4: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come:
mn106:4.5: both of these are Māra’s domain, Māra’s territory, and Māra’s hunting ground.
mn106:4.6: They conduce to bad, unskillful qualities such as desire, ill will, and aggression.
mn106:4.7: And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here.
mn106:4.8: A noble disciple reflects on this:
mn106:4.9: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:4.10: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come:
mn106:4.11: both of these are Māra’s domain, Māra’s territory, and Māra’s hunting ground.
mn106:4.12: They conduce to bad, unskillful qualities such as desire, ill will, and aggression. And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here.
mn106:4.13: Why don’t I meditate with an abundant, expansive heart, having mastered the world and resolved the mind?
mn106:4.14: Then I will have no more bad, unskillful qualities such as desire, ill will, and aggression.
mn106:4.15: And by giving them up my mind, no longer limited, will become limitless and well developed.’
mn106:4.16: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:4.17: Being confident, they either attain the immovable now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:4.18: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the immovable.
mn106:4.19: This is said to be the first way of practice suitable for attaining the immovable.
mn106:5.2: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:5.3: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come:
mn106:5.4: whatever is form, all form is the four primary elements, or form derived from the four primary elements.’
mn106:5.5: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:5.6: Being confident, they either attain the immovable now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:5.7: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the immovable.
mn106:5.8: This is said to be the second way of practice suitable for attaining the immovable.

mn106:6.3: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:6.4: visions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:6.5: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come:
mn106:6.7: And what’s impermanent is not worth relishing, welcoming, or clinging to.’
mn106:6.8: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:6.9: Being confident, they either attain the immovable now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:6.10: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the immovable.

mn106:7.3: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:7.4: visions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:7.5: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:7.8: Where they cease without anything left over: that is peaceful, that is sublime,
mn106:7.10: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.

mn106:8.1: Furthermore, a noble disciple has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
mn106:8.2: ‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’
mn106:8.3: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:8.4: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:8.5: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
mn106:8.6: This is said to be the second way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.

mn106:9.3: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:9.4: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.

mn106:10.4: visions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:10.5: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:10.6: perceptions of the immovable; and perceptions of the dimension of nothingness:
mn106:10.8: Where they cease without anything left over: that is peaceful, that is sublime,
mn106:10.9: namely the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’
mn106:10.10: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:10.11: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:10.12: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn106:10.13: This is said to be the way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”
mn106:11.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
mn106:11.2: Sir, take a mendicant who practices like this:
mn106:11.3: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
mn106:11.7: In this way they gain equanimity.
mn106:11.8: Would that mendicant become extinguished or not?”
mn106:11.9: “One such mendicant might become extinguished, Ānanda, while another might not.”
mn106:11.10: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for this?”
mn106:11.11: “Ānanda, take a mendicant who practices like this:
mn106:11.12: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
mn106:11.16: In this way they gain equanimity.
mn106:11.17: They welcome, relish, and keep clinging to that equanimity.
mn106:11.18: Their consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
mn106:11.19: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.”
mn106:11.20: “But sir, what is that mendicant grasping?”
mn106:11.21: “The dimension of neither perception nor non-percpetion.”
mn106:11.22: “Sir, it seems that mendicant is grasping the best thing to grasp!”
mn106:11.24: For the best thing to grasp is
mn106:11.25: the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn106:12.1: Take a mendicant who practices like this:
mn106:12.2: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
mn106:12.6: In this way they gain equanimity.
mn106:12.7: They don’t relish, welcome, or keep clinging to that equanimity.
mn106:12.8: So their consciousness doesn’t rely on that and grasp it.
mn106:12.9: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.”
mn106:13.2: The Buddha has explained to us how to cross over the flood by relying on one support or the other.
mn106:13.3: But sir, what is noble liberation?”
mn106:13.4: “Ananda, it’s when a mendicant reflects like this:
mn106:13.5: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:13.6: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:13.7: visions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:13.8: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:13.9: perceptions of the immovable; perceptions of the dimension of nothingness; perceptions of the dimension of neither perception or non-perception:
mn106:13.10: that is identity as far as identity extends.
mn106:13.11: This is the deathless, namely the liberation of the mind through not grasping.
mn106:13.12: So, Ānanda, I have taught the ways of practice suitable for attaining the immovable, the dimension of nothingness, and the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. I have taught how to cross the flood by relying on one support or the other, and I have taught noble liberation.
mn106:13.13: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do for the benefit of their disciples.
mn106:13.14: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts.
mn106:13.15: Practice absorption, Ānanda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later!
mn106:13.16: This is my instruction to you.”
mn106:14.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn106:14.2: Uplifted, Venerable Ānanda approved of what the Buddha said.
